content.text: (i) Calculate the number of apple trees.
(ii) Last year in the orchard, the mean mass of fruit produced was 64 kg per tree.
Calculate the total mass of fruit produced last year.
(iii) Last year, the mean mass of pears produced was 54 kg per tree.
This was a decrease of \(10 \%\) on the mean mass of pears produced per tree from the year before.
Calculate the mean mass of pears produced by each pear tree the year before.
(iv) The orchard loses \(\frac{1}{5}\) of its total number of trees in a storm.
Calculate the number of trees that remain.
The trees are in the ratio apple : pear : cherry \(=12:9:4\).
(i) Paulo pays in dollars for 12 pears.
Calculate the change he receives from \(\$ 10\).
Calculate how much more Paulo pays for each pear when he pays in euros.
Give your answer in dollars, correct to the nearest cent.
(b) Paulo buys some pears from a market. Pears cost \(\$ 0.54\) each or 0.51 euros each.
(a) Show that angle \(E B A=32^{\circ}\), correct to the nearest degree.
(c) Calculate the shortest distance from \(E\) to \(A B\).
(d) Calculate the angle \(B F\) makes with the base, \(A B C D\), of the prism.
(e) The prism is made of plastic with density \(938 \mathrm{~kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3}\).
Calculate the mass of the prism in grams.
The diagram shows a solid triangular prism \(A B C D E F\) of length 15 cm . \(A B=6.4 \mathrm{~cm}, E B=5.7 \mathrm{~cm}\) and the volume of the prism is \(145 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\).
(i) Calculate an estimate of the mean.
(ii) An egg is picked at random from the 1000 eggs.
Find the probability that this egg has a mass greater than 56 g .
Give your answer as a fraction in its simplest form.
3 (a) The table shows information about the mass of each of 1000 eggs.
(b) One year, a farmer makes a profit of \(\$ 24730\) selling eggs.
(i) In one year, the mean number of eggs laid per hen was 320 eggs, correct to the nearest 20.
Calculate the upper bound for the total number of eggs all the hens lay in that year.
(ii) Another farm has 800 hens, correct to the nearest 20.
(ii) Another farm has 800 hens, correct to the nearest 20.
Calculate the lower bound for the difference between the number of hens on the two farms.
(c) On a farm, there are 500 hens, correct to the nearest 10.
(i) Calculate the area of triangle \(P Q R\).
The diagram shows a half-cylinder of radius 6 cm and length 11 cm .
Calculate the volume of the half-cylinder.
(i) \(A B C \mathrm{D}\) is a rectangle with \(A B=20 \mathrm{~cm}\) and \(B C=15 \mathrm{~cm}\).
\(S, X\) and \(T\) are points on a circle centre \(O\), such that \(D S A\) and \(D T C\) are tangents to the circle.
The radius of the circle is 4 cm and \(T X\) is a diameter of the circle.
The shape \(D S X T\) is removed from the corner of the rectangle, leaving the shaded shape shown in the second diagram.
Calculate the area of the shaded shape.
(ii) Calculate the perimeter of the shaded shape.
5 (a) There are 160 people in a village. The cumulative frequency diagram shows information about their ages.
(c) the number of people who are 50 or more years of age
6 (a) In the square \(A B C D, A\) has coordinates \((-2,1)\) and \(B\) has coordinates \((1,5)\).
\(C\) has coordinates \((a, b)\), where \(a\) and \(b\) are both positive integers.
Find the coordinates of \(C\) and the coordinates of \(D\).
You may use the grid to help you.
(i) Find the coordinates of the midpoint of \(P Q\).
(iv) Find the equation of the line parallel to \(P Q\) that crosses the \(x\)-axis at \(x=2\).
You must show all your working and give your answers correct to 2 decimal places.
(d) Make \(k\) the subject of the formula.
(a) Write down the other three inequalities in \(x\) and/or \(y\).
On the grid, draw 4 straight lines and shade the unwanted regions to show these inequalities.
Label the region \(R\) that satisfies the 4 inequalities.
(c) Use your diagram to find the smallest number of dresses and the smallest number of shirts the tailor makes in one week.
(d) The profit the tailor makes on one dress is \(\$ 10\) and the profit on one shirt is \(\$ 6\).
Use your diagram to find the largest profit the tailor can make in one week.
8 A tailor makes \(x\) dresses and \(y\) shirts in one week.
- he makes no more than 7 shirts
- he makes less than 14 dresses and shirts altogether
- the number of shirts he makes is more than \(\frac{2}{3}\) of the number of dresses.
One of the inequalities that shows this information is \(x \geqslant 4\).
9 (a) The Venn diagram shows set \(X\) and set \(Y\).
(b) In each Venn diagram, shade the required region.
